awd_titl_txt: An Integrated Instructional Model for Accelerating Student Achievement in  Science and Literacy in Grades 1-2
awd_abstract_narration: Despite over twenty years of educational reform, student achievement in science, along with reading comprehension, has remained a systemic problem for both regular and at-risk student populations. As the national school reform trend reduces time for science instruction in favor of reading across grades K-5, this research and development project, alternatively, is focused on accelerating both student science understanding and reading comprehension proficiency at the primary level (grades 1-2). The project is being implemented in diverse classrooms and addresses age-appropriate content from the areas of the physical, earth/environmental, and life sciences. The project is following a Cluster Randomized Trial (CRT) design with 16 experimental and 16 control schools and a total of 256 teachers/classrooms. Both groups are using the same District-adopted Reading/Language Arts program and are teaching the same District-adopted Science standards that are consistent with frameworks for state and national standards.

por.por_cntn:
• Award Title: An Integrated Instructional Model for Accelerating Student Achievement in Science and Literacy in Grades 1-2
  • Federal Award ID: 1316433
  • Report Submission Period: 09/01/2013 to 08/31/2018

Project Outcomes Report (637 Words)

The purpose of this project was to demonstrate the direct effects in grades 1-2 and the transfer effects in grade 3 of an integrated evidenced-based model, Primary Science IDEAS, in which reading/literacy are  integrated within an in-depth science instructional block in grades 1-2. The intervention was implemented through daily, 45 minute lessons in which a diverse group of students (e.g., 43% Hispanic, 16% African American, 58% Free-Reduced Lunch) across multiple classrooms engaged in a variety of age-appropriate learning activities focusing on core science concepts. All multi-day lessons focused on building cumulative understanding of core science concepts. The instructional activities consisted of reading multiple science trade books and complementary hands-on activities, journaling, age-appropriate concept mapping/writing, and application projects. The effectiveness the intervention was assessed through use of the Iowa Test of Basic Skills (ITBS – a nationally-normed achievement test) using Science and Reading Subtests. Results obtained in year 3 of the project confirmed that the direct effect of intervention in grades1-2 had a significant achievement impact on both science and reading. In addition, the grade 1-2 intervention also obtained a significant achievement transfer effect from grades 1-2 to grade 3 in both ITBS Science and Reading.

Both the direct and transfer effects obtained using the Primary Science IDEAS Model in grades 1-2 extended previous findings obtained in grades 3-4-5 with the Science IDEAS model developed for use with older children. Specifically, the grade 3-4-5 Science IDEAS model has replicated findings in which significant achievement in ITBS Science and Reading have been obtained repeatedly through the direct effects of the model in grades 3-4-5 and through transfer effects from grades 3-4-5 to grades 6-7.

Intellectual Merit. This project incorporated and combined two important interdisciplinary areas of research. These areas, namely cognitive science and instructional design, provided a strong framework for the design and implementation of Primary Science IDEAS. First, Primary Science IDEAS addressed the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) including its’ 3-dimensional teaching model as the means by which the project was able to increase the time for science instruction across grades 1-2. Expanding instructional time for science instruction in grades 1-2 (and previously across grades 3-4-5) is an important element for preparing students for learning in science at the secondary level.

Secondly, the framework supported the empirically-validated Primary Science IDEAS curricular strategy in which improving student reading comprehension proficiency was achieved by integrating literacy (e.g., reading and writing about science) within in-depth science instruction. This finding has important implications for the design of the model as a curricular strategy for improving reading comprehension that would allocate increased instructional time to cumulative science instruction rather than to more typical, narrative-based elementary school reading instructional practices. Such typical elementary school literacy practices have not had a positive nor cumulative impact on elementary reading achievement as evidenced by the National Assessment of Educational Progress. Further, these typical elementary school practices over many decades are contributors to the present lack of student reading comprehension proficiency. The NSF findings also suggest that early learning in science has a broad and transferable impact on student learning across elementary grades.

Broader Impact. When the combination of the integrated Primary Science IDEAS science and literacy instructional model and the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) curricular model is implemented within authentic classroom settings, school districts can begin to address the persistent issues associated with poor achievement trends in early science learning and reading achievement. In doing so, school districts have an evidenced-based rationale for systemically addressing school policies that would substantially increase both time for and the instructional quality of elementary science experiences for early learners across grades 1-3. In turn, with a research-based rationale and the capacity for increasing time for science instruction in grades 1-3, districts can anticipate the subsequent success of students in secondary science and also the promise of improving student reading comprehension proficiency development.
